gml:Dictionary.gml:description: This dictionary contains the values for the propertyClass property of the diggs:Property object and the measurand property of the diggs:Detector object when used within the Test feature, where thetesting procedure is a ProcessedGeophysicalsurvey or WirelineLog. These values serve to define the ultimate results of geophysical field measurements. The Xpaths to these occurrences are: 1) //diggs:Property/diggs:propertyClass.
gml:Dictionary.gml:name: DIGGS Measurement Properties for Geophysics

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The resistance to the propagation of ultrasound waves through a medium.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Acoustic Impedence

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A gravity anomaly, corrected for the height at which it is measured and the attraction of terrain. The height correction alone gives a free-air gravity anomaly.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Bouguer Anomaly

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The measured gravity anomaly after a free-air correction is applied to account for the elevation at which a measurement is made. It does so by adjusting these measurements of gravity to what would have been measured at a reference level, which is commonly taken as mean sea level or the geoid.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Free Air Anamoly

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The reduction of the amplitude of a signal, electric current, or other oscillation during propagation.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Attenuation

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The distance measured across an open borehole.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Borehole Diameter

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Total mass (of solids and water) divided by total volume of material, representing natural conditions
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Density, Bulk (Natural)

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The measured capacitance which is the ratio of delta charge and delta potential
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Capacitance

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The time it takes for a compressional wave to traverse a fixed distance. The reciprocal of p_wave_velocity.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Compressional Slowness

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of the ability of a specified material to pass an electric current.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electrical Conductivity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The ratio of the permittivity of the medium to the permittivity of the free space
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Dielectric Constant

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The ability of a medium to hold an electric charge.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Dielectric Permittivity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The x component of an electric field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: X Component of Electric Field

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The y component of an electric field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Y Component of Electric Field

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The z component of an electric field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Z Component of Electric Field

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The velocity of electromagnetic wave propagation through a medium.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electromagnetic Velocity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The rate of vertical flow of a fluid within a borehole.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Flow Velocity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The intensity of natural gamma-ray radiation emitted from formations containing radioactive elements, such as Potassium, Thorium, and Uranium. Measured according to API specifications or as counts per time
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Gamma Ray

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The acceleration due to gravity (weight/mass) measured in absolute terms.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Absolute Gravitational Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The gradient in the gravitational forces acting on different parts of a nonspherical object.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Gravity Gradient

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The acceleration due to gravity (weight/mass) measured measured relative to some absolute value.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Relative Gravitational Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: the x component of the in-phase wave component.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: X Component of In Phase

diggs:Definition.gml:description: the y component of the in-phase wave component.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Y Component of In Phase

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The hydrogen proton excitation from specific magnetic field frequency based on Earth's field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Larmor Frequency

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The ratio of the flux density to the magnetic field strength.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Magnetic Permeability

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The magnetic field gradient.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Magnetic Field Gradient

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Total strength of the magnetic field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Total Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The x component of a magnetic field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: X Component of Magnetic Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The y component of a magnetic field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Y Component of Magnetic Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The z component of a magnetic field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Z Component of Magnetic Field Strength

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The degree to which a material becomes magnetized in response to an applied magnetic field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Magnetic Susceptibility

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Bulk modulus, denoted by K or B, is defined as a measure of how resistant to compression a substance is.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Bulk Modulus

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Shear modulus, denoted by G, is defined as the ratio of shear stress to the shear strain.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Shear Modulus

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The tangent modulus of the initial, linear portion of a stress-strain curve for material in axial compression or tension is called Young's modulus, also known as the tensile (compression) modulus. It is defined as the ratio of the uniaxial stress over the uniaxial strain in the range of stress in which Hooke's Law holds. It is often calculated using theory of elasticity from other tests.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Young's Modulus

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The amount of detected beta particles in a given time.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Number of Beta Particles

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The amount of detected gamma particles in a given time.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Number of Gamma Particles

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The velocity of a p-wave (Vp). P-waves (primary waves) are compressional waves that are longitudinal in nature.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Primary Compression Wave Velocity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Ratio of the transverse contraction of a body to its longitudinal extension when stretched. Typical values in minerals are from 0.15 to 0.3 (Carbonates:0.15, Sandstones:0.2, Shales:0.25).
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Poisson Ratio

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of transient background potentials that come from the difference in electrolyte mobilities within porous media
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electrodiffusion Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of the amount of work energy needed per unit of electric charge to move the charge from a reference point to a specific point in an electric field.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electric Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of the potential that forms from electrolytes flowing through a porous medium
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electrokinetic Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of the potential from mineral deposit sources
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Mineral Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The potential difference between two electrodes immersed in a homogeonous medium in which local concentration differ
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Nerst Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of the ability of chemical/biochemical systems to oxidize (lose electrons) or reduce (gain electrons).
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Redox Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The x component of the quadrature component (90 degrees out of phase) of transmitted EM energy.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: X Component Of Quadrature

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The y component of the quadrature component (90 degrees out of phase) of transmitted EM energy.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Y Component Of Quadrature

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Radiant energy emitted by radioactive source
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Radiation Energy

diggs:Definition.gml:description: the ratio of amplitude of the reflected wave to the incident wave
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Reflection Coefficient

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The property by which a conductor opposes the flow of electrons, precisely electric current. It is the ratio of voltage to the electric current applied on an electronic device. Resistance is a physical property of the material, and hence, it depends upon the material type. It also depends upon the length and cross-sectional area of the material to which the current is applied. For a material, resistance is proportional to the length and inversely proportional to its cross-sectional area.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electrical Resistance

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The resisting property of the material when the current is applied through it and is defined as the resistance per unit length for a unit cross-section of material. Resistivity is directly proportional to temperature.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Electrical Resistivity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Resistivity between electrodes.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Apparent Resistivity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Acoustic slowness of a shear wave (Vs); reciprocal of Shear_Velocity; a shear wave is a type of seismic wave in which the particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of propagation; also called S-wave or secondary wave.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Shear Slowness

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The velocity of a shear wave (Vs); a shear wave is a type of seismic wave in which the particle motion is perpendicular to the direction of propagation in a horizontal plane ; also called S-wave or secondary wave.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Shear Velocity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: A measure of porosity (defined as the percentage of empty space within a medium) made by comparing the velocity measued by an acoustic logging tool to velocities of the soil/rock matrix and borehole fluid.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Sonic Porosity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Also called self potential, is a naturally occurring electric potential difference in the Earth, measured by an electrode relative to a fixed reference electrode. Spontaneous potentials are usually caused by charge separation in clay or other minerals, due to presence of semi-permeable interface impeding the diffusion of ions through the pore space of rocks, or by natural flow of a conducting fluid through the rocks.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Spontaneous Potential

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The time constant for regrowth of longitudinal magnetization (Mz)
diggs:Definition.gml:name: T1 Time Constant

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The time required for the z-component of M to reach (1 1/e) or about 63% of its maximum value (Mo).
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Longitudinal (Spin-Lattice) Relaxation

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The time constant for decay/dephasing of transverse magnetization (Mxy)
diggs:Definition.gml:name: T2 Time Constant

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The time required for the transverse magnetization to fall to approximately 37% (1/e) of its initial value.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Transverse (Spin-Spin) Relaxation

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The measure of hotness or coldness,.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Temperature

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The force tending to cause extension of a body, as experienced in a cable, rope, string, etc.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Tension

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The x component of the magnetotelluric impedence tensor.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: X Component of Tensor Impedance

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The y component of the magnetotelluric impedence tensor.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Y Component of Tensor Impedance

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The z component of the magnetotelluric impedence tensor.
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Z Component of Tensor Impedance

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Wave velocity that propagates along a steel-cased borehole
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Tube Wave Velocity

diggs:Definition.gml:description: amplitude of borehole wall signals
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Borehole Wall Amplitude

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Borehole wall color image R pixel value
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Image R value

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Borehole wall color image G pixel value
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Image G value

diggs:Definition.gml:description: Borehole wall color image B pixel value
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Image B value

diggs:Definition.gml:description: The two-way time required for a sesimic wave to travel from the source to the borehole wall
diggs:Definition.gml:name: Borehole Wall Travel Time
